subject: AN EXCLUSIVE CBS NEWS INVESTIGATION:  THOUSANDS OF KATRINA VICTIMS ARE STILL IN FEMA TRAILERS....ARE THE TRAILERS TOXIC?
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






QUOTE OF THE DAY"If only we'd stop trying to be 
      happy we could have a pretty good time." - Edith Wharton 
      



DID YOU KNOW?"Second string," meaning "replacement 
      or backup," comes from the middle ages. An archer always carried a second 
      string in case the one on his bow broke. 



TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWSHere is an early preview of what we 
      are planning for tonight's CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing 
      Editor, Katie Couric... Hi everyone, August marks 
      the two-year anniversary of Hurricane Katrina but at least 86,000 families 
      are still living in those white FEMA trailers along the Gulf Coast. While 
      FEMA may have helped shelter a lot of families, our investigative team has 
      discovered that the trailers may be toxic to the people who call them 
      home. Investigative Correspondent Armen Keteyian will report. 
      Sharyl Attkisson is also reporting from the Gulf Coast. 
      Tonight she'll have an update on New Orleans and the surrounding area - 
      how far has it really come since Katrina? In South Carolina last 
      night, Republican presidential candidates took the stage for their second 
      debate. As our senior political correspondent Jeff Greenfield will 
      report, there were more than a few sparks. He'll have the highlights. 
      In health news, we'll look into the Internet and its growing role 
      as a place to find prescription drugs. But, as Wyatt Andrews will 
      report, much of that buying and selling is done illegally without 
      prescriptions - so much that it is catching the attention of legislators 
      on Capitol Hill. Younger and younger kids are using cell phones - 
      and parents are paying the price as kids ring up big bills for games, 
      ringtones and other electronic accessories. The catch: kids don't need a 
      parent's go-ahead before adding charges their bill. Richard 
      Schlesinger will have the story as well as some solutions. 
      Finally, we've got a story about possible Irish roots popping up 
      in an unlikely spot in American politics. According to members of one 
      little church on the Emerald Isle, records show a potential genealogical 
      connection to the 2008 presidential race. I'll give you a hint - 
      his surname isn't O'Malley or O'Connor, but it does start with an "O." 
      I hope you'll join us, Katie For 
      more information on these stories, please click on the following 
      links: Brits Nix Prince Harry Iraq Tour Click 
      Here GOP Candidates Sharpen Their Attacks Click 
      Here And here's a look at one of the stories we're working 
      on for Thursday's broadcast: Credit card companies are now 
      targeting HIGH SCHOOL KIDS...getting them hooked on PLASTIC. Part of our 
      series Gotta Have It: The Hard Sell to Kids. This story and much 
      more, Thursday, on the CBS Evening News. If you 
      would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, 
      please click on the following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 



TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANJoin Dave tonight on The Late 
      Show with actor Ricky Gervais AND actress Mary 
      Lynn Rajskub... Also, don't miss a Top Ten List presented by The Price 
      Is Right host Bob Barker. Plus, musical guest Mavis Staples! 
      



THURSDAY MORNING 
      ON THE EARLY SHOWHarry Smith, Hannah Storm, Julie 
      Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor THE EARLY 
      SHOW from New York. Dave Price will 
      bring us the weather Along with the top news of the day, we 
      will also have the following stories: GOTTA HAVE IT: ALPHA 
      MOMS: The "Alpha Mom" is educated, affluent and in charge. She sets 
      the trends, and controls over $500 billion dollars of total spending. That 
      is why companies are so interested in targeting "Alpha Moms" with their 
      products. As we continue our series Gotta Have It, we'll see why 
      these mothers may be influencing the way YOU spend. EARLY SHOW National Correspondent Tracy Smith will have details. 
      FAREWELL TO BOB BARKER, PART 2: Bob Barker's final "Come on 
      Down" is coming up fast. But before he leaves The Price is Right 
      for good, Bob will be honored Wednesday night with a prime time special, 
      looking back at a half-century of work on the small screen. EARLY 
      SHOW National Correspondent Hattie Kauffman finds out what 
      Bob is leaving behind: the adoration of game show contestants from across 
      the nation. JUST ASK A WOMAN. . . ABOUT HER LOOKS: 
      Wednesday morning we continue our Just Ask A Woman series by 
      looking at women and beauty. In fact, the anti-aging industry reportedly 
      racks in over $50 billion dollars a year in sales. EARLY 
      SHOW Contributor Mary Lou Quinlan will 
      join us with more. PET PLANET: GENTLE BARN: A California 
      woman has devoted her life to rescuing abused and unwanted farm animals 
      and giving them a second chance. But she's not stopping there. Those 
      animals are now helping children with troubled lives of their own. The 
      result is pretty amazing. Our resident veterinarian, Dr. Debbye 
      Turner will share with us in Wednesday morning's Pet Planet. 
      ANTONIO BANDERAS ON SHREK THE THIRD: When Spanish 
      heartthrob Antonio Banderas made his Hollywood film debut in 1992's 
      Mambo Kings, he didn't speak any English. Now he supplies his voice 
      to the ever so suave Puss In Boots, who returns in the new animated film 
      Shrek The Third. Wednesday morning, Antonio will join us to discuss 
      the latest Shrek film. NEW YORK LIBERTY: WNBA players Shay 
      Doron, Tiffany Jackson, Jessica Davenport, and the NY Liberty Mascot will 
      join us to talk about the upcoming season. We'll shoot some hoops with the 
      basketball stars out on our plaza. BILL GEIST ON WAY OFF THE 
      ROAD: For twenty years, Bill Geist has delivered the big news 
      from some of America's smallest towns. And, the Correspondent best known 
      for his reporting for CBS News' Sunday Morning, has often taken us on quite an adventure. From flying with a 
      paperboy pilot, to challenging a watermelon champion speed eater, these 
      exploits and many more are featured in Bill's new book, Way Off The 
      Road: The Peculiar Charms of Small-Town America. Monday morning, Bill 
      will join us for more on his adventures and his latest book. 
      BOBBY FLAY'S HOT DOGS: Summer is the perfect time to fire 
      up the grill and take advantage of the weather by cooking outside. Whether 
      you are cooking for two or for a Memorial Day weekend get-together, 
      grilling delicious favorites is quick and easy. How can you make the best 
      tasting ballpark frank right at home? Our resident chef Bobby Flay 
      will join us for a special taste of summer hot dogs. CSI 
      PREVIEW: The nail-biting season finale of CSI airs Thursday 
      night. The CSI team is closing-in on the so-called "Miniature 
      Killer," with Grissom going as far as making his OWN "miniature" to get 
      inside the murderer's mind. Thursday morning, we'll get an exclusive 
      "sneak peek" from the episode in which the team gets a surprising clue 
      into the killer's identity. If you would like more information on 
      any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following 
      address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com 



 
"THAT'S THE WAY 
      IT IS: CELEBRATING CRONKITE AT 90" FRIDAY, MAY 18TH (8-9pmET/PT)
The world is a very different place than it was in the 1960s and 
      '70s when one voice seemed to speak for all Americans and, in so doing, to 
      bind the nation together. That unique and iconic voice was, of course, 
      Walter Cronkite's. CBS News will celebrate the legendary newsman's 
      singular life and career in a CBS News primetime special, "THAT'S 
      THE WAY IT IS - CELEBRATING CRONKITE AT 90," to be broadcast 
      Friday, May 18th (8:00-9:00 PM, ET/PT) on the CBS Television Network.
